question_text: A 26-year-old woman is evaluated for a 5-year history of lower abdominal pain and weight loss. A colonoscopy is performed.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is Crohn colitis (Option B). A characteristic mucosal feature of Crohn disease seen on colonoscopy is the so-called “skip lesion,” consisting of affected areas separated by normal mucosa. Other endoscopic findings of Crohn disease include aphthous ulcers, which can coalesce to form stellate ulcers, and a “cobblestone” mucosal appearance.
